summary: I am a Singaporean born and raised chef, based in Melbourne. I graduated with an Honors’ degree in Food Science and Technology but decided to trade in my lab coat for chef whites. I have since worked in restaurants in Singapore and Australia, including Candlenut and Carlton Wine Room. In 2019, I published the cookbook Wet Market to Table to encourage young Singaporeans to return to the wet markets and to be excited by regional produce. The book became a national bestseller and is currently in its fourth print. The celebration and preservation of Singapore’s food heritage being my passion, I launched Singapore Noodles in 2020 as a go-to destination for anyone to discover real Singaporean food.

profile_positions.description:
Singapore Noodles imagines a Singapore in which its people are proud of the rich & diverse food culture that we have, and play an active role in keeping our food heritage alive. We now stand at the crossroads where we are witnessing the vanishing of traditional dishes and the gradual erosion of our rich food culture. Now more than ever, we have to encourage one another to get into the kitchen.

profile_positions.description:
Seasonings Magazine is an independent quarterly publication that celebrates diversity in Singapore through the lens of food and culture.

In the past, it was commonplace for Singaporeans to invite friends into their houses to share food, exchange recipes, and celebrate festivals together, regardless of race or religion. These rich cultural exchanges have now become a rarity – we live alongside one another, but do we really know our neighbour?

Seasonings Magazine explores the ways in which food is not only an expression of our identity, but can also bring us together and establish common ground. Through recipes, stories, and deep-dives, we hope that you will feel a sense of interconnectedness and be inspired to venture outside of your comfort zone.

profile_positions.description:
Daylesford Longhouse is a place of residence, working farm and cooking school – all in one. While most houses provide a sense of retreat from the outside world, Daylesford Longhouse brings the outside in, allowing guests to enjoy both the farm life and the comfort of a home.

Daylesford Longhouse is composed of living quarters, a garden kitchen and a working farm building – all within one, long shed structure. The house is not your usual weekender – it has been designed for living, working, storing and making. It is intentionally active and demands constant care and attention from owners Trace & Ronnen, be it milking a cow, making cheese or pruning a tree. It is a place that takes you back to the fundamentals of living.

profile_positions.description: Wet Market to Table, published in 2019, aims to show how regional ingredients found in the wet markets in Singapore could be jumping off points for new and exciting dishes in the kitchen. But beyond inspiring culinary creativity, this book is a young Singaporean’s love song to the wet markets. As much as it is a celebration of regional produce, it also pays tribute to the people who run it and a way of life that is gradually phasing out. Sprinkled with a scattering of stories, the book provides information and modern recipes on how best to select, store, prepare and cook with 25 ingredients that are unique to the wet market. The first print of the cookbook sold out within the first month of sales and made The Straits Times and Kinokuniya bestseller lists in Singapore.
